sections: Good things are happening! Sure, between the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, the accelerating climate crisis, and now the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the world is on edge. But we at
have compiled several positive recent stories to suggest that hope is not lost.

First, President Joe Biden passed over potential Supreme Court justice frontrunner Judge Michelle Childs, a union buster propped up by Lindsey Graham, and instead nominated Judge Kentaji Brown Jackson, a former public defender whose recent court history suggests she could be a bit more welcoming to labor efforts. On top of that, despite the risks, dissident voices in Russia are speaking out against Russian President Vladimir Putin’s Ukraine invasion. Finally, a California union just scored a major win for ice cream cake makers. Victory has never tasted so sweet.
All that and much more in this week’s week’s edition of You Love To See It, exclusively for paying subscribers below.

On Friday, Biden instead announced he was nominating Judge Kentaji Brown Jackson of the Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit to replace Breyer.

Brown, a former public defender, could prove to be a better choice. Earlier this month, in her first appeals court ruling, Brown sided with public sector unions against the Federal Labor Relations Authority when the agency tried to heighten bargaining requirements for public-sector workers. Workers at the Jon Donaire Desserts plant in Santa Fe Springs, California, have

after a 113-day strike, securing a $3.10 wage increase over four years and blocking a plan to cut their health care benefits. More than 150 workers, who make ice cream cakes for companies like Baskin Robbins, Cold Stone Creamery, Walmart, Red Robin, and Safeway, had gone on strike in early November, demanding a $1 raise every year for three years and no healthcare cost increases.

Dakota Access Legal Battle Ends In Pipeline Loss
After six long years, the legal battle over the Dakota Access Pipeline is over. The Supreme Court
declined to take up an appeal by Energy Transfer
, the operator of the pipeline, after a lower court handed a victory to the Standing Rock Sioux and other North Dakota tribes.

The ruling, which will now stand, invalidated a key federal permit for the pipeline on the grounds that it violated the National Environmental Policy Act. The court required the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to conduct a comprehensive environmental review of the pipeline’s route underneath Lake Oahe, on the border of North and South Dakota, which Indigenous communities
consider sacred and have historically relied on
. Although the court battle was won, however, the
war of the pipeline’s fate continues
. The pipeline has been operating since 2017 and will continue to do so while the environmental review is completed.
NLRB Tells Starbucks to Kick Rocks

Starbucks baristas are unionizing. Workers at several stories in upstate New York have petitioned for union elections, following the lead of their colleagues in the Buffalo area. But the company has been trying to slow the elections, asking the National Labor Relations Board not to move forward with voting on the grounds that all stores in the region should vote together in one election. Unfortunately for the company, its attorneys missed a crucial deadline with the NLRB after they failed to turn in all of their paperwork on time. The company missed the cutoff just eight minutes.
As a result of the missed deadline, the NLRB’s regional director

that the company was precluded “from litigating any of the issues raised in its untimely Submission,” despite the company’s attorneys arguing the union, Workers United, “suffered no prejudice” from the delay. The company can appeal the regional director’s order in Washington.

sent a letter to Starbucks’ CEO on Wednesday in support of the Starbucks Workers United union, urging the company to “follow the letter and spirit of the law by allowing your employees free choice in joining a union.”

Know Your Rights Camp, a group founded by former NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick, is

free second autopsies for families of people killed in circumstances involving police. The group will provide second opinions that have been previously widely unavailable due to high costs. Families often have to rely on the work of the local medical examiner or coroner, opening the door for individual biases to impact the outcome.

while studying sea beds that could prove useful in the fight against climate change. Researchers found that sea beds are host to far greater biodiversity than the oceans above them with many unknown lifeforms. Among the organisms found were plankton that fall to the seafloor and sequester carbon for millions of years. According to the paper published by the researchers, the findings “highlight previously underappreciated taxa that may be keystone drivers of the biological carbon pump.”
